summary: This is a defense expert disclosure filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team in her criminal case. It outlines the expected testimony of two expert witnesses, Dr. [REDACTED] and Dr. [REDACTED], who will challenge the reliability of witness memories, critique the concept of 'grooming,' and discuss cognitive biases like hindsight bias and the halo effect as they relate to the allegations against Maxwell. This document is a defense filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, providing notice of expert witnesses the defense intends to call. It includes extensive discussion of psychological pathways to false allegations of sexual assault and lists several experts in psychiatry, law, computer forensics, financial investigation, and document examination who will testify for the defense.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The document is a defense filing outlining expert testimony intended to challenge the prosecution's case against her.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from the law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., who is submitting the defense expert disclosure on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A Distinguished Professor of Psychological Science and Law at UC Irvine, identified as a leading expert on memory science. The defense expects her to testify about the fallibility of memory, the creation of false memories, and the effects of suggestion.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the individual for whom Maxwell allegedly recruited minors. The document notes he pleaded guilty to having sexual contact with post-pubescent minors and discusses his personality traits and manipulation of others.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein discussed different kinds of power and his attraction to powerful people.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of a person with political power.

persons.name: Gerry Edelman
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of a person with intellectual power.

persons.name: Dr. M
persons.context: Expert who performed an independent medical and psychiatric evaluation of a witness (likely a victim) in 2009. Will testify that the witness did not identify Maxwell as a perpetrator.

persons.name: Professor
persons.role: Law Professor / Expert on Prosecutorial Misconduct
persons.context: Distinguished Professor of Law at Pace University, former prosecutor. Expected to testify on best practices to ensure prosecution integrity.

persons.name: Mr.
persons.context: CEO of Forensic Pursuit with over 25 years experience. Will testify about user data, documents, photographs, and metadata from seized devices.

persons.name: Mr. I
persons.context: Former IRS Special Agent with over 25 years experience. Will testify about his review of financial records and fund transfers provided in discovery.

persons.name: Ms.
persons.context: Trained by the U.S. Secret Service. May analyze documents for authorship, authentication, dates of creation, alteration.

persons.name: Emily R. Dworkin
persons.context: Cited author of meta-analysis on risk for mental disorders associated with sexual assault.

persons.name: Caron Zlotnick
persons.context: Cited author of study on chronicity in PTSD and predictors of course.

persons.name: Meredith Warshaw
persons.context: Co-author with Caron Zlotnick on the PTSD study.

connections.description: The document states Maxwell is accused of recruiting and grooming minors to provide sexualized massages for Epstein, characterizing it as an alleged 'grooming-by-proxy' relationship.
Pagliuca is submitting the expert disclosure as counsel for defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Dr. [REDACTED] is a defense expert witness retained to provide testimony challenging the prosecution's case against Maxwell.
Epstein gave a videotaped interview to Steve Bannon where he discussed power and influential people.
Epstein cited Clinton as an example of political power, indicating a perceived association.
Dr. M is an expert witness retained by the defense to evaluate a witness and provide testimony favorable to Maxwell's defense.
Professor is an expert witness retained by the defense to testify on prosecutorial misconduct and best practices.
Mr. is a computer forensics expert retained by the defense to analyze digital evidence.
Mr. I is a financial investigation expert retained by the defense to analyze financial records.

events.title: Defense Expert Disclosure Filed
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a summary of expected expert witness testimony pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea Referenced
events.description: The document references that Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to having sexual contact with post-pubescent minors, which is cited as an outcome that creates hindsight bias.

events.title: Psychiatric Evaluation of Witness
events.description: Dr. M performed an independent medical and psychiatric evaluation of a witness (referred to as 'Ms.').

events.title: Defense Expert Witness Disclosure
events.description: Defense files notice of intent to call multiple expert witnesses in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 10th Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80203
University of California, Irvine School of Law
University of Virginia School of Law
keyFacts: The defense plans to call expert witnesses to challenge the reliability of witness memories, arguing that false memories can be created through suggestion, media coverage, and discussions with others.

A defense expert strongly criticizes the prosecution's use of the term 'grooming,' arguing it imputes motive without evidence, lacks a consistent definition, and that a theory of 'grooming-by-proxy' has no scientific support.

The defense intends to present testimony on cognitive biases, specifically hindsight bias (overestimating predictability after knowing an outcome) and the halo effect (positive traits influencing perception of unrelated characteristics), as they relate to evaluating the case against Maxwell.
The document references a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein discussed being attracted to different kinds of power, citing figures like Bill Clinton and Gerry Edelman as examples.
A defense expert outlines multiple psychological pathways to false allegations of sexual assault, including lying, false memories, implied consent, and various personality disorders.

The defense outlines multiple psychological pathways that could lead to false allegations of sexual assault, including false memory, intoxication, antisocial personality disorder, borderline personality disorder, histrionic personality disorder, delirium, psychotic disorders, dissociation, and intellectual disability.
The defense intends to call Dr. M, a forensic psychiatrist, who evaluated a witness in 2009 and will testify that the witness did not identify Ghislaine Maxwell as a perpetrator of any abuse.
The defense is calling a computer forensics expert (Mr.) to analyze user data, documents, photographs, and metadata from devices seized by the government.
The defense is calling a financial investigator (Mr. I), a former IRS Special Agent, to analyze financial records and fund transfers provided in discovery.
The defense reserves the right to call additional expert witnesses and to rebut testimony about 'grooming' or other opinions after the government's case-in-chief.
